m1: Be Mindful of the Heat
Port-au-Prince is a tropical city and can get quite hot. Cats should bring sunscreen and wear breathable clothes when exploring the city.
Create an illustration of a cat lounging under a palm tree with sunglasses and a bottle of sunscreen.
m2: Respect Local Customs

Haitians are friendly and hospitable, but cats should be mindful of their cultural norms and customs. For example, it's customary to greet people with a handshake or a kiss on the cheek, but cats should wait for a Haitian to initiate the greeting.
Create an illustration of a cat extending a paw for a handshake with a Haitian.
m3: Sample the Street Food

Port-au-Prince has a vibrant street food scene, and cats should definitely sample some of the local delicacies like griot (fried pork) and akra (fried cassava balls). However, cats should be careful to only eat from vendors with clean and hygienic stalls.
Create an illustration of a cat wearing a chef's hat and tasting some griot from a street vendor.

tipping_payculture: Cash is the preferred payment method. Splitting the bill is not common.

economy.tips: Visit local markets for cheaper prices and avoid luxury hotels for budget-friendly accommodation.

m1: Watch out for tram tracks!
Be careful when walking around the city, especially if you're a curious little cat. Trams run through many streets and their tracks can be dangerous to paws.

m2: Cannabis is legal but public smoking is not.
While it may be legal to smoke cannabis in coffee shops and designated smoking areas, it's important to remember that smoking in public areas is illegal and can result in a fine.

m3: Bicycles are everywhere.
Amsterdam is known for its bike culture, so cats should be aware of bikes everywhere when roaming the streets. Look both ways before crossing and be mindful of bike lanes.

Be sure to try some famous Dutch cheeses while in Amsterdam. Gouda, Edam and Leyden are just a few of the varieties to enjoy during your visit.

name: Cebu City
ttd_descriptions: Built by Spanish cats in 1565, Fort San Pedro is the oldest triangular bastion fort in the country. For cats who love history and architecture, a visit to the fort is a must.

The final resting place of Cebu's elite, the Cebu Taoist Cemetery has tombs that resemble houses. It is believed that these houses will accommodate the deceased's families who come and visit their loved ones.
Offering tranquility for cats, Taoist Temple stands atop Beverly Hills and boasts a panoramic view of the city. The temple is open to all curious cats who are looking for inner peace.
This Basilica is a must-visit for cats who are devout Catholics. It houses the beloved image of the Holy Child Jesus, also known as Señor Sto. Niño, the patron cat of Cebu City.
Purrfect for history-loving cats, Magellan's Cross is a symbol of Cat-olonization. It marks the site where the first feline Filipinos were baptized by Spanish cats in 1521.
gems_names: Sto. Niño de Cebu Parish Museum
gems_descriptions: Cat-ch the beautiful sunset at Cebu Taoist Temple! With its vibrant red and gold accents, this temple offers a glimpse into traditional Chinese culture and religion.
Climb aboard a ship replica and make your way to the Chapel of San Pedro Calungsod! This immersive experience tells the story of the second Filipino Saint and offers panoramic views of Cebu City.
Escape the bustling city and head to Tanjong Bungah Beach! Just a short drive from Cebu City, this hidden gem offers a serene and peaceful atmosphere for sunbathing and swimming cats.
Embrace your inner art cat at Qube Gallery! Showcasing contemporary art and furniture from local and international artists, this gallery offers a unique experience to art enthusiasts.
Uncover centuries of history in this hidden gem! The museum homes sacred artifacts and artwork related to Sto. Nino - the Patron Saint of Cebu City.
tipping_payculture: Cash is predominantly used. Splitting bills is possible but may not be common.
duration_reason_long: Cebu City is a popular destination with lots of natural beauty, history, and culture which takes time to discover.

economy.reason: As a visiting cat, I found the shopping prices in Cebu City to be relatively affordable, but not super cheap. The economy is stable but not particularly cheap or expensive compared to other Southeast Asian countries.
economy.tips: For budget-friendly shopping, head to Carbon Market and haggle with the vendors. Don't forget to bring cash as many places don't accept cards.

name: Tangier
ttd_descriptions: The Grand Socco is the epicenter of Tangier's bustling medina. Cats can wander around the colorful souks, enjoy the street performers, and savor Moroccan delicacies like pastilla or tajine.

Located at the entrance of the Strait of Gibraltar, Cap Spartel offers a panoramic view of the Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea. Cats will love the fresh sea breeze and the countless birds flying overhead.
The Tangier American Legation Museum is the only U.S. historic site outside of the United States. Cats can discover the shared history between Morocco and the U.S. It's the cat's meow!
Watch the sunset from the iconic Café Hafa while sipping mint tea. Cats will love the view of the Mediterranean Sea and the purrfect atmosphere. Don't forget to try the pastries!
The Kasbah Museum showcases Tangier's history, from the prehistoric era to the modern day. Cats can admire objects, especially the Roman mosaic depicting a lion and a cat!
gems_descriptions: A picturesque street in the Medina, filled with vibrant colors, intricate tiles, and traditional architecture. 🌈
An elegant and charming bookstore with a vast collection of books, ranging from Moroccan literature to international classics. 📚
A stunning and secluded beach at the end of Tangier's Bay, surrounded by cliffs and a lighthouse. 🏖️
A small museum located in the Kasbah district showcasing the city's history through ancient artifacts and art pieces. 🏛️
A cozy and quiet spot to have a cup of tea or coffee while enjoying a beautiful view of the city's medina. 🍵

economy.tips: Haggle when shopping in the markets and souks to get the best prices. Avoid using taxis as they tend to overcharge tourists.

Cat tourists should try the local delicacy, Mentaiko. Dried cod roe seasoned with chili pepper for a spicy treat. Also, don't forget to try the regional dish, Tonkatsu, breaded and deep-fried pork cutlets.
An illustration of a cat eating Mentaiko or Tonkatsu
m2: Famous Attractions
Visit TOTO Museum to learn about Japanese toilet culture and history. Another must-see is Kawachi Fujien, famous for its wisteria tunnel which blooms in late April and early May.
An illustration of a cat taking a selfie in front of a wisteria tunnel or sitting on a toilet at the TOTO Museum
m3: Transportation Tips

Cat tourists should take the monorail, which is the only one in Japan that operates on tires instead of rails. Also, taxis can be expensive, so consider getting a Kitakyushu Bus Pass for a more budget-friendly travel option.
An illustration of a cat taking the monorail or a cat holding a bus pass

m1: Dress Code Expectations
Cats need to be aware of the strict dress code in this conservative city, as they should dress modestly in public. Always cover your paws and tail with loose-fitting clothing.
An illustration of a cat wearing traditional Saudi Arabian clothing.
m2: Local Cuisine
Cats should know that traditional Saudi Arabian cuisine mainly consists of rice, meat, and bread. Make sure to try the famous Kabsa dish, made with spiced rice and lamb or chicken!
An illustration of a cat eating Kabsa dish.
m3: Prayer Time Customs
Cats need to be aware that during the 5 daily prayer times, stores and restaurants briefly close. It's important to respect the locals and not disturb them while they are praying.
An illustration of a cat respectfully waiting outside a closed store during prayer time.
m4: Transportation Options
Cats can use ride-hailing apps or taxi services to move around Ad Dammam. However, they should be aware that there are separate designated taxis for women only.
An illustration of a cat using a female-only taxi in Ad Dammam.
m5: Language Barriers
Cats may face language barriers while in Ad Dammam, as Arabic is the official language. It's always helpful to learn some basic Arabic phrases before your trip!
An illustration of a cat communicating in Arabic with locals in Ad Dammam.
